Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Transcranial MRI-Guided Focused Ultrasound Surgery for Glioblastoma

Trial_Design.evidence: three glioblastoma patients were recruited based on specific eligibility criteria at a single clinical center

Participants.evidence: three glioblastoma patients were recruited based on specific eligibility criteria at a single clinical center

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to receive multiple focused ultrasound exposures using a hemispherical phased array transducer with patient-specific treatment planning

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate the clinical feasibility of transcranial MRI-guided focused ultrasound surgery (TcMRgFUS) as a noninvasive alternative to surgical resection for glioblastoma

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the ability to achieve controlled and precise thermal ablation in the brain, assessed through MR temperature imaging over a defined timeframe

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed with sealed envelopes

Blinding.evidence: Due to the nature of the intervention, blinding was not applicable to patients or clinicians

Result_Outcome.evidence: The trial demonstrated the feasibility of focusing an ultrasound beam transcranially into the brain and visualizing the heating with MR temperature imaging

Harms.evidence: No adverse events were reported during the study period
